messageBody:
I see that some of my thoughts have been reiterated, and agreed with
by some. As for my consonant alphabet, I've temporarily put it
aside, and am sticking to the Read Alphabet. In my opinion,
standardized spelling is quite possible. I believe that it is best
based on American English (NBC English, as I've seen it referred to
as), as it's the most common variety of English (as far as I know).
I don't know who would be threatened by the use of American English
as the basis for standardized spelling, but if anyone had a problem,
they'd have said so by now, I do believe. To me, there are two ways
to view spelling:
1) Being able to read a word, and sound it out phonetically, and
2) Recognizing each individual word's spelling (as is the case with
English, whether you want to admit it or not)
Even if standardized spelling is based on American English, people
all over the world will start to recognize the spelling of each
individual word, as one would have to do anyway to be able to read
English.

Alternately, different spellings could be devised for both American
English and British/Australian English, and could be used somewhat
interchangeably as standard spellings.

One last thing: Whether you realize it or not, spelling as we know it
today is based (at least loosely) on that of older varieties of
English (i.e. 'laugh' used to be pronounced 'lawkh,' with 'kh' being
the 'ch' in 'loch'), so it still does not adequately reflect modern
English pronunciation.


Charles
